basics.name: Natalie E Wright
basics.label: Material Culture Scholar
basics.summary: Natalie Wright is the Charles Hummel Curatorial Fellow at the Chipstone Foundation. Wright completed her MA at the Winterthur Program in American Material Culture in 2015, and received her BA in Diaspora and Transnational Studies at the University of Toronto in 2013. Wright has contributed to Chipstone exhibitions Apartment 4: Iris Häussler and The Chipstone Foundation, Florence Eiseman: Designing Childhood for the American Century, and Mrs. M.-----’s Cabinet. During her time as a Curatorial Assistant at the Canadian Museum of History, she contributed to the exhibit Terry Fox: Running to the Heart of Canada. Wright has lectured internationally on the materiality of empathy, and has published on the history of clothing for persons with disabilities. Her research on objects carried across the Pacific Ocean after the 2011 Japenese tsunami will be published in the forthcoming University of Delaware Press edited volume Fugitive Archives.

work.summary: The Chipstone Foundation in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, is devoted to exploring new directions in both object-based study and museum practice. Chipstone has a remarkable collection of early American and British decorative arts that they curate in five galleries at the Milwaukee Art Museum, in addition to collaborating with a huge array of other institutions on exhibits and courses. As a result of the new curatorial practices that they have fostered, Chipstone now runs a Think Tank program to encourage a culture of innovation in arts organizations.
highlights: Assisted with exhibits Apartment 4: Iris Häussler and The Chipstone Foundation (2018, John Michael Kohler Arts Center), Florence Eiseman: Designing Childhood for the American Century (2017, Museum of Wisconsin Art), and Mrs. M.-----’s Cabinet (2016, Milwaukee Art Museum).
Assisted with teaching classes visiting Chipstone from institutions including the Bard Graduate Center, Harvard University, and the University of Wisconsin.
Helped to organize large events such as Think Tanks with leading cultural institutions, as well as Chipstone's annual Object Lab program.

Oversaw Chipstone digital initiatives including: moderating exhibit websites for Mrs. M.-----'s Cabinet and Apartment 4, and producing Chipstone podcasts, radio episodes, and videos for exhibits and teaching.
Researched objects in the collection and potential acquisitions.
Oversaw Chipstone Social Media presence and outreach.
Assisted with digitizing the Chipstone collections through Embark.

work.company: University of Delaware Center for Material Culture Studies
work.summary: The Center for Material Culture Studies at the University of Delaware aims to promote and support scholarship and innovative pedagogy in the study of material culture. The Center has emerged as a hub for faculty and graduate students across a wide variety of disciplines. The Center also provides a nexus for the exchange of information on national and international developments in material culture studies.
highlights: Created a new website for the Center as a platform to share the research initiatives that the Center makes possible across disciplines at the University of Delaware and nationally.

work.summary: Canada's national museum of history has a collection of over four million objects, with concentrations in the fields of history, archaeology, ethnology and cultural studies. For four months, I worked with Dr. Sheldon Posen, Curator of Canadian Folklife.
highlights: Conducted research to develop key themes for the exhibit “Terry Fox: Running to the Heart of Canada,” including examining the Terry Fox story through a disability studies lens.
Used Google Maps to create an interactive map of events associated with the Terry Fox run.
Worked full-time for three consecutive summers to help with hiring practices including conducting interviews and tests, and corresponding with applicants.
Gathered and organized data from all High Commission employees to create a safety contact flow chart in the event of an emergency.

work.summary: Creature is a small, independent advertising agency that works on projects ranging from campaigns for the British Red Cross to co-producing immersive theater productions.
highlights: Examined relationships to sport in Eastern European and Middle Eastern countries.
Communicated this research for colleagues to create a pitch to Nike.

work.summary: UCL has a strong focus on Material Culture Studies through the Anthropology department with Master's programs in Material and Visual Culture, Materials Anthropology Design, and Digital Anthropology.
highlights: Worked with anthropologist Dr. Daniel Miller for two months to investigate how Diasporic communities in London utilized Skype. Dr. Miller used this research in his 2014 publication Webcam (Polity Press).
Conducted and transcribed interviews with and for Dr. Miller.

work.summary: The Royal Geographical Society (London, ENG) has a collection of over two million items relating to histories of geographic research. They both interpret this collection and support new generations of geographers.
highlights: Conducted research for an online exhibit interpreting the failed 1845 Franklin Expedition to the Northwest Passage.
Used Google Earth to pinpoint important locations in the Franklin Expedition based on indigenous oral histories.
